author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The God of High School’ and ‘Personal Problems’
description: The Crunchyroll original anime series makes its debut. And the final film by the director Bill Gunn arrives on Mubi.
content: THE GOD OF HIGH SCHOOL Stream on Crunchyroll. In East Asian animation, educational institutions are more than just common settings. They’re often portrayed as crucibles within which the transformation from childhood to adult life occurs. The main character in this new series from Crunchyroll, an adaptation of the online comic by Yongje Park, is a high school student and taekwondo practitioner named Jin Mo-Ri who is invited to participate in a fighting tournament along with others in his age group. The competitors use their cultivated skill as well as power borrowed from the gods to try to advance. But gods aren’t the only supernatural entities that exist within this world: Demons are real, too, and they’ve clashed with humans in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pooja Reddy
title: Could We Fight Misinformation With Blockchain Technology?
description: The Times’s Research and Development team conducted an experiment in surfacing news photos’ metadata to help ensure they would be used to advance the truth.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: From ‘Game of Thrones’ to Digital Couture
description: Carice van Houten, the Red Priestess, brings an Iris van Herpen dress to life in a short film.
content: In March, it was decided that the couture collections as everyone knew them — the ultimate visual extravaganzas of fashion artistry, handmade for the very few — should be canceled, because of the coronavirus pandemic. But then designers and the industry bodies that represent them said fah! to all that and declared the shows would go on, albeit as digital experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Trump’s Us vs. Them Holiday
description: The president uses July 4 to lay out his message of division: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Trump envisions “far-left fascism,” and Kanye West jumps into the presidential race — maybe. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Craftsman house in Los Angeles, a chalet-style home in Tahoe City and a 1924 bungalow in San Anselmo.
content: This house is in the West Adams section of Los Angeles, one of several examples of Craftsman-style architecture on its block. Built in 1906 for an executive of a lumber company, it is within the boundaries of the West Adams Terrace Historic Preservation Overlay Zone. The current owner bought the property in 2010 and has spent a decade restoring it, updating the HVAC, electrical and plumbing systems, while preserving the charm of its original details. Many of the fixtures came from the going-out-of-business sale of a popular salvage store.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.5 Million in California
description: A Craftsman house in Los Angeles, a chalet-style home in Tahoe City and a 1924 bungalow in San Anselmo.
content: A Craftsman house in Los Angeles, a chalet-style home in Tahoe City and a 1924 bungalow in San Anselmo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Russian Court Convicts Journalist for ‘Justifying Terrorism’
description: The case against the freelance reporter revolved around a 2018 text critical of the security services. Even the Kremlin’s human rights council had denounced the charges.
content: MOSCOW — Further tightening the screws on free speech in Russia just days after a national plebiscite effectively entrenched Vladimir V. Putin as president for life, a Russian military court on Monday convicted a freelance journalist on charges of “justifying terrorism” in a 2018 text critical of the security services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner
title: In Her Words: 7 Issues, 7 Days
description: Learn about seven next-to-invisible inequities that women in the U.S. face every day.
content: Learn about seven next-to-invisible inequities that women in the U.S. face every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner
title: 7 Inequities: A Weeklong Look at the Biases Women Face
description: Double standards abound from the salary she earns to the unpaid hours she works.
content: Women are living in a world that’s made for men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: An Unlikely Source of Catharsis for a Black M.L.B. Player: Social Media
description: Tony Kemp felt depressed after George Floyd’s death in police custody. Then he invited fans to have uncomfortable conversations on Twitter.
content: Tony Kemp felt, in his words, depressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: A Kennedy and a Professor Compete to Run Against a Trump Backer
description: Stakes are high in the Democratic primary for a New Jersey congressional seat: The winner will face a candidate who defected from the party to support Trump.
content: Jeff Van Drew’s defection from the Democratic Party began with a vote against impeaching President Trump and ended with a handshake in the Oval Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloë Ellingson
title: Commuting, and Confronting History, on a Remote Canadian Railway
description: The Tshiuetin line, the first railroad in North America owned and operated by First Nations people, is a symbol of reclamation and defiance for the communities it serves.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Chloë Ellingson shares a collection of photos from a remote railway in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Primary Election Results: 24th Congressional District
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: Live: Virginia State Primary Election Results 2020

title: New York Presidential Democratic Primary Election Results
source.name: The New York Times

title: North Carolina Republican Primary Runoff Election Results: 11th Congressional District
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Primary Election Results: 11th Congressional District
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Michael LaForgia and Hailey Fuchs
title: Trump Vowed to ‘Drain the Swamp,’ but Lobbyists Are Helping Run His Campaign
description: Lobbyists like David Urban, whose connections start at the very top, are thriving as they help the president’s re-election effort while aiding corporate clients.
content: WASHINGTON — The chief executive of the arms maker Raytheon, under pressure to overcome a congressional hold on major sales in the fall of 2018, wanted to sit down with one of the few people who could solve the problem — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Wooden Cutting Boards Arrive From Australia
description: These camphor laurel boards are handsome, antibacterial and available in a range of sizes.
content: In 1993, a study was published showing that wooden cutting boards had antibacterial qualities that caused them to be them safer than plastic. An Australian company that makes handsome cutting boards from sustainable camphor laurel trees is hailing its product’s antibacterial quality, which it says was confirmed by the Australian National Association of Testing Authorities. The richly grained boards come in a wardrobe of sizes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Evidence continues to build around the risks of transmission at places like bars, restaurants and parties.
content: Elected officials in the United States are beginning to acknowledge that the rush to reopen was a mistake, as many of the hardest-hit areas in recent weeks have been places that lifted lockdown restrictions fastest. And one factor seems to be playing an outsize role in the uptick: indoor transmission from businesses like bars and restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: British Foreign Secretary Announces New Human Rights Sanctions
description: The British foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, said the new sanctions were part of an effort to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender.
content: The British foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, said the new sanctions were part of an effort to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: ‘We Are Still Knee-Deep in the First Wave,’ Fauci Warns
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Monday that he did not consider the increase in U.S. coronavirus cases a wave, but rather a resurgence of infections.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Monday that he did not consider the increase in U.S. coronavirus cases a wave, but rather a resurgence of infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Hip-Hop’s Deluxe Editions Rule the Billboard Album Chart
description: The Atlanta rapper Lil Baby notched a fifth week at No. 1 and Lil Durk returned to No. 2 with recently refreshed releases.
content: During a slow summer for the music industry, the 25-year-old Atlanta rapper Lil Baby has been a consistent bright spot. This week, in its 18th go-round on the Billboard chart, his album “My Turn” logged its fourth consecutive — and fifth overall — stay at No. 1, adding another 70,000 units, according to Nielsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: British Foreign Secretary Announces New Human Rights Sanctions
description: The British foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, said the new sanctions were part of an effort to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender.
content: The British foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, said the new sanctions were part of an effort to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Ennio Morricone, Oscar-Winning Composer of Film Scores, Dies at 91
description: His vast output included atmospheric music for spaghetti westerns in his native Italy and scores for some 500 movies by a Who’s Who of directors.
content: Ennio Morricone, the Italian composer whose atmospheric scores for spaghetti westerns and some 500 films by a Who’s Who of international directors made him one of the world’s most versatile and influential creators of music for the modern cinema, died on Monday in Rome. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Winnie Hu
title: Why New York Buses Are on the Rise in a Subway City
description: During the coronavirus pandemic, daily ridership on buses has surpassed the subway for the first time in over half a century.
content: In the battle for riders, New York City’s subway has always trounced buses. By a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: As the Virus Surged, Florida Partied. Tracking the Revelers Has Been Tough.
description: With the coronavirus exploding, trying to trace the contacts of every positive case has become unrealistic in Florida, especially among elusive partygoers.
content: MIAMI — Miami’s flashy nightclubs closed in March, but the parties have raged on in the waterfront manse tucked in the lush residential neighborhood of Belle Meade Island. Revelers arrive in sports cars and ride-shares several nights a week, say neighbors who have spied professional bouncers at the door and bought earplugs to try to sleep through the thumping dance beats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: N.H.L. and Players Agree to Start Postseason Tournament on Aug. 1
description: The two sides agreed to extend the current collective bargaining agreement, setting the stage for a resumption of play that will reportedly be hosted in Edmonton and Toronto.
content: The National Hockey League and its players’ union announced on Monday that the two groups agreed on a four-year extension to the current collective bargaining agreement, a pivotal decision that paves the way for hockey to resume play amid the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: 64 Shot, 10 Dead: Spike in Gun Violence Alarms an On-Edge N.Y.C.
description: The victims included a young father who was shot while holding hands with his 6-year-old daughter in the Bronx.
content: A young father crossing a Bronx street, holding hands with his 6-year-old daughter. A 15-year-old who refused to talk to the police in Manhattan. A man in a Staten Island public housing complex, found prone in his apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Won’t Cross the Border for Washington Summit
description: Mr. Trudeau was invited to the meeting this week to celebrate the official start of a new trade deal. But as Canada’s coronavirus preventer-in-chief, he hardly could go, experts said.
content: TORONTO — He sent his regrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Lauren Messman
title: Phoenix Police Kill Man in Parked Car, Igniting New Protests
description: The fatal shooting, captured on video, comes at a time when cities around the United States are grappling with anger over deaths at the hands of the police.
content: The fatal shooting of a man in a parked car by Phoenix police officers over the weekend, captured on video in gruesome detail, is fueling a new round of protests against violent policing tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Can We Please Pick the President by Popular Vote Now?
description: The Supreme Court’s unanimous decision in the “faithless electors” case is another reminder of how antiquated and undemocratic the Electoral College is.
content: The Supreme Court clearly got it right on Monday when it ruled that the Electoral College can keep working the way it has worked for the last 200 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Luke Broadwater
title: Lobbyists, Law Firms and Trade Groups Took Small-Business Loans
description: The Trump administration began releasing details of which businesses received Paycheck Protection Program aid.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, under pressure to reveal which companies received loans from a $660 billion program intended to keep small businesses afloat, on Monday released data showing that restaurants, medical offices and car dealerships ranked high among the top loan recipients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: In Nick Cordero’s Death, a Reminder of Covid-19’s Unknowns
description: The Broadway star died from the coronavirus, despite being just 41 and in apparent good health. Cases like his, experts said, are growing.
content: The death of the Broadway actor Nick Cordero from Covid-19 has shaken people far beyond the theater world, in large part because he was just 41 and reportedly had no underlying health conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: ‘It’s Got to Stop’: Atlanta’s Mayor Decries a Surge of Violence as a Girl Is Killed
description: Secoriea Turner, 8, was one of several children killed across the country over the holiday weekend. Her death has roiled Atlanta.
content: ATLANTA — Activists with Black Lives Matter had a vision for what the scorched remains of a Wendy’s restaurant could become: the Rayshard Brooks Peace Center, a gathering place in Atlanta with job training, counseling and youth programs that would be a living memorial named for the man whose fatal encounter with the police transformed the fast-food eatery into the heart of the city’s turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Can Cam Newton Be Superman Again?
description: Newton went from paradigm-shifting M.V.P. to discarded free agent. Joining the New England Patriots could give him the perfect relaunch.
content: Third-and-10 is traditionally a passing situation, but just outside the red zone on that down, Cam Newton took the shotgun snap, glanced left, tucked the ball and charged forward. Evading a thicket of bodies, he cut right and accelerated toward the sideline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Denies U.S. Request to Extradite Operator of Child Pornography Site
description: The Justice Department had sought to try Son Jong-woo after he was indicted by a federal grand jury in the District of Columbia on money-laundering and other charges.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court on Monday rejected an extradition request by the United States for a South Korean citizen convicted of running one of the world’s biggest child pornography websites on the dark web.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: Jarvis Cocker Keeps Hearing That Voice
description: Returning with a new band, Jarv Is …, the onetime Pulp leader explains how David Bowie saved his life and why he can’t give up songwriting — yet.
content: “Here’s one of the most exciting things that’s happened to me recently,” said Jarvis Cocker, British rock’s foremost chronicler of hedonistic urges among the educated classes. One leaned in, expecting a rollicking anecdote. “I was given a membership to the London Library,” he revealed. “It’s a private library, in London, surprisingly, that’s been there for about 300 years.” (He was only off by 122 years; it was founded in 1841.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Two Top New York City Culinary Schools Join Forces
description: The International Culinary Center will become part of the Institute of Culinary Education by the end of the year.
content: By the end of the year the International Culinary Center, formerly the French Culinary Institute, will close its doors in SoHo and will become part of the Institute of Culinary Education in the Brookfield Place complex in Battery Park City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Kwame Onwuachi Is Leaving Kith and Kin in Washington
description: The chef said that he would seek a restaurant of his own. Paola Velez, the restaurant’s executive pastry chef, has also left, to work with two Washington restaurants.
content: A month ago, the chef Kwame Onwuachi reopened Kith and Kin, the restaurant on the Potomac River in Washington where he established himself as a national talent and a leading voice for Black workers in the culinary profession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Dulce Nunes, Bossa Nova Star of the 1960s, Dies at 90
description: She was best-known for the 1964 album “Poor Little Rich Girl.” Ms. Nunes died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Virus, Confederate Flag, Amy Cooper: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Scientists Insist Airborne Spread Is a Threat as the W.H.O. Wavers
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 6, 2020.
content: “At the moment we have to make a decision in the face of uncertainty, and my goodness, it’s going to be a disastrous decision if we get it wrong. So why not just mask up for a few weeks, just in case?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Langer
title: These Radical Black Thrillers Fantasized About Dismantling the Police
description: In the late 1960s and early 1970s, a series of novels by Black authors married revolutionary politics with pulp fiction. Their plotlines remain distressingly relevant.
content: You could almost say these novels predicted their own fates. A telling bit of dialogue appears midway through “Operation Burning Candle,” Blyden Jackson’s 1973 thriller about a Black disciple of Jungian psychoanalysis who fakes his death in Vietnam and returns to America with a group of other veterans to take down the white establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Four New Insights About the Coronavirus
description: A look at what scientists have learned about how the virus takes hold in the body and where the risk of infection is highest.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Pandemic First: Actors’ Union Will Allow Two Shows, With Testing
description: Theaters in the Berkshires are planning live shows, “Godspell” and “Harry Clarke,” with limited audiences and virus-related protocols in place. One will be indoors, and one outdoors.
content: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic erupted, Actors’ Equity is agreeing to allow a few of its members to perform onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: Virus, Confederate Flag, Amy Cooper: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Pandemic First: Actors’ Union Will Allow Two Shows, With Testing
description: Theaters in the Berkshires are planning live shows, “Godspell” and “Harry Clarke,” with limited audiences and virus-related protocols in place. One will be indoors, and one outdoors.
content: For the first time since the coronavirus pandemic erupted, Actors’ Equity is agreeing to allow a few of its members to perform onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Wine Getaway
description: New York Wine Events now offers winery tours, transportation included, for small groups of up to 12.
content: For a way to get out of the house, you can now gather friends and family from your quarantine bubble and take a personal wine tour of the North Fork of Long Island or the Hudson Valley led by New York Wine Events. Open to groups of two to 12, the tour hits the road from Manhattan with private tours and tastings at two wineries as well as a stop at a farm stand. Transportation is provided, and lunch is optional. Health protocols are observed, and the excursion lasts about nine hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Slurp Oysters From the Eastern Seaboard
description: Need oysters for the raw bar at home? Many producers will ship them fresh to your door.
content: Like cheese makers, those who cultivate oysters along America’s coastlines have also felt the loss of restaurant business during the pandemic. Though it’s long been possible to order fresh oysters, shipped to your door, from some of these oyster farms, there are more to choose from now. (Oysters keep in the refrigerator, unopened, for more than a week.) Then you can either plan on roasting or steaming them open or arm yourself with a proper knife and protective glove — some of the farms also sell the gear. Here are some sources: Peeko Oysters, New Suffolk, N.Y., peekooysters.com; Montauk Pearls, Montauk Shellfish, 631-902-7829 for local delivery; Stella Mar Oyster Company, Stamford, Conn., stellamaroysters.com; Island Creek Oysters, Duxbury, Mass., islandcreekoysters.com; and goldbelly.com supplies oysters nationwide directly from Mook Sea Farms in Maine, Wellfleet Shellfish Company in Massachusetts, and White Stone Oyster Company and Rappahannock River Oysters in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neha Chaudhary, M.D
title: Rituals Keep These Athletes Grounded. They Can Help Parents, Too.
description: With stress levels high during the pandemic, every day can feel like overtime. Here’s how to take back control.
content: Each time my dad, a third-degree black belt in taekwondo, put on his dobok, he would stop and kiss his belt before tying it around his waist. As a kid, I thought it was just a superstition, like tossing a penny into a fountain. But he recently told me kissing the belt was actually to honor it, set an intention and to say, “I will do my best today while wearing this, no matter what comes my way.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Wharton
title: Meet the Gleaners, Combing Farm Fields to Feed the Newly Hungry
description: An age-old tradition suddenly has fresh urgency in the pandemic, delivering surplus produce to Americans who can’t feed their families.
content: SPRINGFIELD TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Armed with a cheap steak knife and a plastic basket lined with a garbage bag, a high-school sophomore named Alicia Garlic sat cross-legged in the dirt at Specca Farms, a pick-your-own operation here in South Jersey. As the sun burned through the early morning clouds, she harvested curly-leaf spinach as fast as she could, lopping the sweet green tops off yellowing plants, trimming away thickening stems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Students’ Calls to Remove a Mural Were Answered. Now Comes a Lawsuit.
description: An alumnus has filed a suit to save a fresco at the University of Kentucky that depicts enslaved people; a Black artist whose work is shown with it also wants the mural to stay.
content: For years, there has been a simmering debate over what to do with a New Deal-era mural at the University of Kentucky that students have denounced as a racist sanitizing of history and a painful reminder of slavery in a public setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Simon & Schuster Names Dana Canedy New Publisher
description: Ms. Canedy, a former journalist at The New York Times and the administrator of the Pulitzer Prizes, will run the namesake imprint at one of the country’s largest book publishers.
content: Simon & Schuster on Monday named Dana Canedy senior vice president and publisher of its namesake imprint, putting a former journalist in one of the biggest jobs in book publishing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: There Are Ways to Avoid Layoffs
description: A human resources association offers suggestions. Also: Remote learning works.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: A New Generation of Fast Coronavirus Tests Is Coming
description: New technologies, like the gene-editing tool Crispr, can spot the virus in less than an hour. But it will likely be months before these tests hit clinics.
content: Researchers around the world are working on the next generation of coronavirus tests that give answers in less than an hour, without onerous equipment or highly trained personnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Patrick Mahomes Gets 10-Year Deal With Kansas City Chiefs
description: Mahomes, 24, signed an extension worth $503 million on the heels of a Super Bowl win.
content: Quarterback Patrick Mahomes, one of the N.F.L.’s biggest stars, has signed a 10-year contract extension with the Kansas City Chiefs, according to a person familiar with the terms of the deal who was not authorized to speak for the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Lisa Friedman
title: Dakota Access Pipeline to Shut Down Pending Review, Federal Judge Rules
description: The ruling, a victory for the Native American and environmentalist groups who oppose the pipeline, said that it must be emptied of oil by Aug. 5.
content: The Dakota Access Pipeline, an oil route from North Dakota to Illinois that has inspired intense protests and legal battles, must shut down pending an environmental review and be emptied of oil by Aug. 5, a district court ruled on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Students’ Calls to Remove a Mural Were Answered. Now Comes a Lawsuit.
description: An alumnus has filed a suit to save a fresco at the University of Kentucky that depicts enslaved people; a Black artist whose work is shown with it also wants the mural to stay.
content: For years, there has been a simmering debate over what to do with a New Deal-era mural at the University of Kentucky that students have denounced as a racist sanitizing of history and a painful reminder of slavery in a public setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Simon & Schuster Names Dana Canedy New Publisher
description: Ms. Canedy, a former journalist at The New York Times and the administrator of the Pulitzer Prizes, will run the namesake imprint at one of the country’s largest book publishers.
content: Simon & Schuster on Monday named Dana Canedy senior vice president and publisher of its namesake imprint, putting a former journalist in one of the biggest jobs in book publishing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: There Are Ways to Avoid Layoffs
description: A human resources association offers suggestions. Also: Remote learning works.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Block Ruling to Halt Work on Keystone XL Pipeline
description: But the justices stayed the rest of a federal trial judge’s ruling striking down a permit program, allowing construction of other pipelines around the nation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday rejected a request from the Trump administration to allow construction of parts of the Keystone XL oil pipeline that had been blocked by a federal judge in Montana. But the court temporarily revived a permit program that would let other oil and gas pipelines cross waterways after only modest scrutiny from regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: 356 Elephants Died Suddenly. The Cause Is a Mystery.
description: Some conservationists say the recent die-off in Botswana could be natural, but others expressed more concern.
content: On May 25, conservationists were flying over Botswana’s Okavango Panhandle when they counted something disturbing: 169 dead elephants. A second flight in June revealed more carcasses, bringing the total to 356. Some of the animals appeared to have died suddenly, collapsing chest-first while walking or running. No tusks were removed, suggesting that poaching for ivory may not be to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Britain, Charting Its Own Course on Human Rights, Imposes New Sanctions
description: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announced that dozens of people from Russia and Saudi Arabia would be added to a blacklist, but China was notably absent.
content: LONDON — Britain, seeking to carve out a post-Brexit role as a human-rights defender, said on Monday it had blacklisted dozens of people from Russia, Saudi Arabia and Myanmar for abuses ranging from a carefully-plotted execution to jailhouse beatings and the persecution of Rohingya refugees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert E. Rubin and David Miliband
title: Borders Won’t Protect Your Country From Coronavirus
description: Rich nations need to help poor ones now. It’s morally right — and in everyone’s self-interest.
content: The coronavirus has hit the poorest the hardest, but until recently, they have mostly been in wealthy countries. Now, even as the pandemic continues to claim lives in high-income countries — and especially the United States — it’s spreading with ferocity in lower- and middle-income countries. The virus has infected at least 1.5 million people in Brazil and claimed more than 60,000 lives there. India ended June with around 600,000 cases; it started the month with just under 200,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dolnick
title: (Let Us Out of This Clause)
description: At last, I had seen the true absurd hopelessness of things, laid out in flawless prose.
content: A few years ago I got a note from a reader (written in the tone of patient disappointment with which you might discuss pants-wearing with a naked toddler) about parentheses. I used altogether too many of them, apparently. I tried to make them hold more than their listed storage capacity. I may as well have stamped the page with coffee rings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Trump Supports Washington Team Name. Retailers Pull Merchandise.
description: Walmart and Target removed the N.F.L. team’s products from their websites as pressure intensified to change the name, a consideration the president said was motivated by political correctness.
content: The battle over the name of the Washington, D.C., N.F.L. team deepened on Monday as President Trump defended it even as more retailers said they would pull the team’s gear off their shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Nick Cordero, Nominated for Tony as Tap-Dancing Tough Guy, Dies at 41
description: The Broadway actor’s battle with the coronavirus was followed closely by many as his wife chronicled his experience on social media.
content: Nick Cordero, a musical theater actor whose imposing height — 6 feet 5 inches — and effortless charm brought him a series of tough-guy roles on Broadway, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Simon & Schuster Advances Publication Date of Trump Tell-All
description: The release of “Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the World’s Most Dangerous Man,” by Mary Trump, is now scheduled for July 14.
content: Responding to an increase in publicity and advance orders, Simon & Schuster announced on Monday that it was planning to release a tell-all book by Mary L. Trump, President Trump’s niece, on July 14, two weeks earlier than originally scheduled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert E. Rubin and David Miliband
title: Borders Won’t Protect Your Country From Coronavirus
description: Rich nations need to help poor ones now. It’s morally right — and in everyone’s self-interest.
content: The coronavirus has hit the poorest the hardest, but until recently, they have mostly been in wealthy countries. Now, even as the pandemic continues to claim lives in high-income countries — and especially the United States — it’s spreading with ferocity in lower- and middle-income countries. The virus has infected at least 1.5 million people in Brazil and claimed more than 60,000 lives there. India ended June with around 600,000 cases; it started the month with just under 200,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Uighur Exiles Push for Court Case Accusing China of Genocide
description: The complaint at the International Criminal Court is the first of its kind to challenge Beijing on its crackdown on Muslims, but China does not accept the court’s jurisdiction.
content: Uighur exiles urged the International Criminal Court on Monday to investigate Beijing for genocide and crimes against humanity, the first-ever attempt to use international law to hold China’s ruling Communist Party accountable for its draconian crackdown on the Muslim minority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dolnick
title: (Let Us Out of This Clause)
description: At last, I had seen the true absurd hopelessness of things, laid out in flawless prose.
content: A few years ago I got a note from a reader (written in the tone of patient disappointment with which you might discuss pants-wearing with a naked toddler) about parentheses. I used altogether too many of them, apparently. I tried to make them hold more than their listed storage capacity. I may as well have stamped the page with coffee rings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: New York City’s Biggest Decision: How to Safely Reopen Schools
description: The plan now emerging could have an enormous impact because the local economy may not fully recover until working parents can send children to school.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to reopen New York’s public schools in September, but students will almost certainly not return to classrooms five days a week, and they will probably have staggered schedules to fulfill social-distancing requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Spencer Cox Wins Utah’s G.O.P. Primary for Governor, Beating Jon Huntsman
description: Mr. Cox, the state’s lieutenant governor, is expected to win the general election as well. He had the endorsement of Gov. Gary Herbert, who rose to his office after Mr. Huntsman left it.
content: Lt. Gov. Spencer Cox of Utah won last week’s Republican primary for governor, according to results released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Catalonia Lockdown, Croatia Election, Prince Andrew: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Living With Your Desk Mates
description: Five work colleagues, living alone during the pandemic, decide to rent a house in the country and quarantine together.
content: This spring, as the months of quarantine dragged on and Taylor Mecham’s three roommates left their Lower East Side apartment to stay with family outside the city, she found herself longing for some non-remote companionship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phil Klay
title: Can the Trauma of War Lead to Growth, Despite the Scars?
description: When we speak of trauma, it is usually as something to be avoided at all costs. But the suffering that war brings can be a strange and terrible blessing.
content: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minna Dubin
title: ‘I Am Going to Physically Explode’: Mom Rage in a Pandemic
description: With coronavirus concerns, stay-at-home orders, financial instability and mounting civil unrest, it is no surprise that mothers are experiencing intensified anger.
content: After I wrote a personal essay on mom rage in 2019, strangers on Twitter declared me an unfit mother. But I expected Twitter-hate. What I did not expect were the many emails I received from mothers around the world, saying they too struggle with mom rage and my story made them feel less alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Global Comparison of Coronavirus Cases
description: Some countries responded aggressively from the start of the pandemic, while others instituted lockdowns and began reopening carefully after initial outbreaks. Then there’s the U.S.
content: Above is a more detailed version of the chart — showing new coronavirus cases, adjusted for population — that ran in today’s edition of The Morning newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: The Next Phase of Reopening
description: Nail salons and tattoo parlors reopen, but indoor dining remains on hold, considered too risky given coronavirus outbreaks elsewhere.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How Netflix Beat Hollywood to a Generation of Black Content
description: The company didn’t set out to build a big library of Black programming, but now it’s the envy of its rivals.
content: The Black documentarian Stanley Nelson says his phone has been “ringing off the hook” as America is looking again at racism and the Black experience. Justin Simien, the creator of “Dear White People,” says the reactions to his pitches have grown warmer. And the director Ava DuVernay reports a flood of calls to “me and every other Black person that’s ever picked up a camera.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: As Coronavirus Cases Rise, the Federal Work Force Heads Back to the Office
description: Federal employees are being ushered back to office buildings under inconsistent and conflicting reopening plans, against the wishes of leaders in the nation’s capital.
content: WASHINGTON — As coronavirus cases surge around the country and epidemiologists urge caution, the federal government is heading back to work, jeopardizing pandemic progress in one of the few regions where confirmed infections continue to decline: the nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: Are Protests Dangerous? What Experts Say May Depend on Who’s Protesting What
description: Public health experts decried the anti-lockdown protests as dangerous gatherings in a pandemic. Health experts seem less comfortable doing so now that the marches are against racism.
content: As the pandemic took hold, most epidemiologists have had clear proscriptions in fighting it: No students in classrooms, no in-person religious services, no visits to sick relatives in hospitals, no large public gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kentucky U.S. Senate Primary Election Results
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: Kentucky Presidential Republican Primary Election Results

title: Live: South Carolina State Primary Runoff Election Results 2020
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Primary Election Results: Second Congressional District
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: ‘Hamilton’ and the Historical Record: Frequently Asked Questions
description: The Disney+ filmed version has fans wondering what’s accurate. Historians are fans, too, and they have answers, along with caveats.
content: When “Hamilton” premiered onstage in 2015, the musical attracted a big following among historians, who were delighted by Lin-Manuel Miranda’s unabashedly nerdy attention to primary documents and the scholarly literature.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live: Kentucky State Primary Election Results 2020
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live: Kentucky State Primary Election Results 2020
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Quince Paste by Request
description: An American food importer provided the inspiration for this spicy pâte de fruits from Provence, France.
content: Kitty Keller, the founder of the importer KL Keller Foodways, has a favorite French maker of pâte de fruits in Provence, François Doucet. Over a dinner at King, she persuaded him to make a paste she had been thinking of for years: quince (like the Spanish membrillo, often served with cheese) seasoned with espelette, a spice she adores from the Basque Country. The result is a small ruddy block of a densely fruity yet tart confection, with a kick. Serve it with cheese or gently melt it to make a glaze for pork. Use a slice of it instead of jelly in your PB&J, and that sandwich will never be the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Airborne Coronavirus: What You Should Do Now
description: How to protect yourself from a virus that may be floating indoors? Better ventilation, for starters. And keep wearing those masks.
content: The coronavirus can stay aloft for hours in tiny droplets in stagnant air, infecting people as they inhale, mounting scientific evidence suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Erin Griffith and Adam Satariano
title: Uber Buys Postmates for $2.65 Billion
description: The ride-hailing company’s core business has struggled in the pandemic, so it is betting on the growth of its Uber Eats division.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber has agreed to acquire the food delivery start-up Postmates for $2.65 billion as it aims to expand its presence in on-demand food delivery while its core ride-hailing business struggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Seized by the Police, an Outspoken Chinese Professor Sees Fears Come True
description: Xu Zhangrun, who has long taught law at the prestigious Tsinghua University, is one of the few academics in China who have harshly criticized the ruling Communist Party.
content: The Chinese law professor had stored a few pairs of underwear and a toothbrush in a small bag, close at hand for the day when the police detained him for his unsparing criticism of the Communist Party under Xi Jinping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Katie Glueck
title: Biden’s Big Climate Decision: Will He Embrace His Task Force’s Goals?
description: The former vice president’s allies and some of the Democratic Party’s leading progressives have quietly started to forge common ground to shape a climate plan before Election Day.
content: WASHINGTON — From the earliest days of his presidential campaign, progressive climate advocates viewed Joseph R. Biden Jr. with deep skepticism. He declined to fully endorse the Green New Deal. He opposed a total ban on fracking. Young activists were scathing in their criticism of him, and he was at times openly dismissive of their concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Asher and Ben Horwitz
title: It’s Been ‘Such a Weird Year.’ That’s Also Reflected in Crime Statistics.
description: In large cities across America, murders are up sharply, while other violent crimes have decreased.
content: The national numbers for murder and other types of violent crime rarely move in opposite directions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: How a Covid-19 Vaccine Could Cost Americans Dearly
description: The United States is the only developed nation unable to balance cost, efficacy and social good in setting prices.
content: Yes, of course, Americans’ health is priceless, and reining in a deadly virus that has trashed the economy would be invaluable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How America Lost the War on Covid-19
description: It wasn’t because of our culture, it was because of our leadership.
content: When did America start losing its war against the coronavirus? How did we find ourselves international pariahs, not even allowed to travel to Europe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Adds to Playbook of Stoking White Fear and Resentment
description: With a defense of Confederate flags and a false accusation against a Black NASCAR driver, Bubba Wallace, President Trump is focusing on racial and cultural flash points to appeal to his base.
content: President Trump mounted an explicit defense of the Confederate flag on Monday, suggesting that NASCAR had made a mistake in banning it from its auto racing events, while falsely accusing a top Black driver, Darrell Wallace Jr., of perpetrating a hoax involving a noose found in his garage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fauci Says Virus Cases ‘Never Got Down to Where We Wanted to Go’ as Deaths Pass 130,000
description: Texas and Idaho set daily records for new cases. Two Texas sheriffs say they won’t enforce the governor’s order requiring residents to wear masks in public. Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms of Atlanta said that she tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, warned on Monday that the country was still “knee-deep in the first wave” of the pandemic, as U.S. deaths passed 130,000 and cases neared three million, while Texas and Idaho set daily records for new cases, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: How Badly Is America Doing?
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: When can schools safely reopen? When will the economy really start recovering? And when will you next eat in a restaurant, go to a movie, watch pro sports or hang out at a friend’s house?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Warren Buffett Is Back in the Game
description: The acquisition of a gas pipeline is Berkshire Hathaway’s largest in years, quelling investor anxiety about its recent drought of deal-making.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Police Seek 2 White People Who Were Seen Vandalizing Black Lives Matter Mural
description: “I’m not so surprised that it happened,” said the mural’s organizer, Justin Gomez. “I’m surprised at how bold they chose to be.”
content: The police in Martinez, Calif., said on Sunday that they were seeking two white people who were seen vandalizing a Black Lives Matter mural less than an hour after it was painted in front of a local courthouse on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: If the Teeth Fit …
description: For all its brooding and disfigured corpses, the series is also showing it has a lighter side.
content: Sister Alice is out to sea. Literally. In the shot that ends this week’s episode of “Perry Mason,” the charismatic preacher is shown blissfully adrift in her tiny ship, figuratively kept afloat by her conviction that God has spoken to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Mendoza, Jacob Amaro, Yeimy Gamez Castillo and Johnathan Christie
title: What We Learned in 100 Days of Life Interrupted
description: Four first-generation college students in Newark, N.J., tell the story of the pandemic, their uprooted plans — and what they found out.
content: Young people in the United States are living through interesting times, as the coronavirus pandemic uproots the country’s economy and changes what college will look like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Our Cash-Free Future Is Getting Closer
description: The pandemic is propelling a shift toward a cashless society in ways that no other single event has. Experts say that’s not necessarily a good thing.
content: PARIS — On a typical Sunday, patrons at Julien Cornu’s cheese shop used to load up on Camembert and chèvre for the week, with about half the customers digging into their pockets for euro notes and coins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lesley Evans Ogden
title: Hair From Ghostly Bears Reveals New Genetic Secrets
description: First Nations peoples along British Columbia’s Central Coast led research to help preserve the area’s white-furred Spirit bears.
content: Douglas Neasloss was skeptical that Spirit bears existed. A member of the Kitasoo/Xai’xais First Nation in Canada, he had heard the stories of white-furred bears that roamed British Columbia’s rainforest. But Mr. Neasloss, a former tour leader and cultural interpreter, had never seen one until 2005, when he experienced “one of the most magical moments” of his guiding career. During a hike, he caught sight of a cinnamon-tinged white bear as it walked out ahead of him, then lay down 50 feet away to munch on a freshly caught salmon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Police Seek 2 White People Who Were Seen Vandalizing Black Lives Matter Mural
description: “I’m not so surprised that it happened,” said the mural’s organizer, Justin Gomez. “I’m surprised at how bold they chose to be.”
content: The police in Martinez, Calif., said on Sunday that they were seeking two white people who were seen vandalizing a Black Lives Matter mural less than an hour after it was painted in front of a local courthouse on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: If the Teeth Fit …

content: Sister Alice is out to sea. Literally. In the shot that ends this week’s episode of “Perry Mason,” the charismatic preacher is shown blissfully adrift in her tiny ship, figuratively kept afloat by her conviction that God has spoken to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: YouTube’s Power of the Purse
description: YouTube shows that some constructions of digital spaces can help combat online nastiness.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Treasury Says Small-Business Loans Supported Over 50 Million Jobs: Live Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: Restaurants, medical offices and car dealerships were the top recipients of large loans from the federal government’s $660 billion small business relief program, according to data released Monday by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Pilots Were Once in Short Supply. Now They’re Losing Their Jobs.
description: Before the pandemic, airlines worried about not being able to replace retiring baby boomers. Eager recruits expect to bear the brunt of layoffs.
content: Joshua Weinstein always wanted to be an airline pilot, but the industry was in crisis when he started college in 2002, so he became a middle school teacher instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Charlie Daniels, Fiddling Force in Country and Rock, Dies at 83
description: He was a singer, songwriter, bandleader and a blazing fiddle player on hits like “The Devil Went Down to Georgia.” His politics swung, too, from left to right.
content: NASHVILLE — Charlie Daniels, the singer, songwriter and bandleader who was a force in both country and rock for decades, bringing a brash, down-home persona and blazing fiddle work to hits like “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” died on Monday in Nashville. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: N.Y.C. Reopening: Dog Runs and Manicures, but Still No Indoor Dining
description: The city took its narrowest reopening step yet as it welcomed the return of personal-care services and outdoor recreation spaces.
content: In the five years that Alyson Araque had been getting her nails done at a salon in Manhattan, she had never before been required to do what a receptionist asked on Monday: to wear a face mask. To wash her hands. To wear gloves during her pedicure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: The Next Energy Battle: Renewables vs. Natural Gas
description: As coal declines and wind and solar energy rise, some are pushing to limit the use of natural gas, but utilities say they are not ready to do so.
content: Dominion Energy, one of the nation’s largest utilities, in late June erected wind turbines off the Virginia coast — only the second such installation in the United States — as part of a big bet on renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Fiery Attack at Mount Rushmore
description: Readers discuss the president’s call for a defense of U.S. monuments, his portrayal of the left as fascists and his comment that Covid-19 was almost always “totally harmless.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Louise Donovan
title: Laid Off and Locked Up: Virus Traps Domestic Workers in Arab States
description: The pandemic and economic crises have caused many workers to lose their jobs. Some have been detained, abused, deprived of wages and stranded far from home with nowhere to turn for help.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When the nine African women lost their jobs as domestic workers in Saudi Arabia because of the coronavirus lockdown, the agency that had recruited them stuffed them in a bare room with a few thin mattresses and locked the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Two Horses Trained by Baffert Test Positive for Banned Substances
description: The horses failed tests of a second sample, confirming the presence of an unauthorized local numbing agent.
content: Two undefeated horses trained by the Hall of Famer Bob Baffert indeed tested positive for a banned substance in Arkansas, a person familiar with the results of the split-sample test said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour Nixes Plan to Have Fans at the Memorial Tournament
description: The event had the approval of state and local officials to host a limited capacity of spectators when it opens in Dublin, Ohio, on July 16, but scrapped those plans citing rising Covid-19 cases.
content: The PGA Tour’s Memorial Tournament, scheduled next week in central Ohio, had hoped to pave the way for spectators to return to golf events during the coronavirus pandemic, and in turn perhaps provide a blueprint for how fans could safely attend other major American sports competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: TikTok to Withdraw From Hong Kong as Tech Giants Halt Data Requests
description: Google, Facebook and Twitter said they were reviewing China’s punitive new national security law for the city, a rare public questioning of Chinese policy by major American tech companies.
content: Google, Facebook and Twitter said on Monday that they would temporarily stop processing Hong Kong government requests for user data as the companies reviewed a sweeping national security law that has chilled political expression in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Appeals Court Strikes Down Trump Administration’s Asylum Ban
description: Although the ban remains in place for now, the ruling is a legal setback for one of the government’s most important policies aimed at slowing immigration.
content: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court on Monday struck down President Trump’s policy that barred most migrants from seeking asylum in the United States if they had passed through another country, concluding that the government did “virtually nothing” to make sure that another country is “a safe option” for those fleeing persecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lacy Crawford
title: How to Sell Your Rape Story
description: There’s nothing special about my story. That’s the point.
content: 1. Know that, to rise to the attention of media gatekeepers, your rape story must clear a bar that love and murder and adventure and dragon stories don’t have to clear and be either horrible (gang rape, deep lacerations) or gilded (see No. 2).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucian K. Truscott IV
title: I’m a Direct Descendant of Thomas Jefferson. Take Down His Memorial.
description: Monticello is shrine enough for a man who wrote that “all men are created equal” and yet never did much to make those words come true.
content: When my brother Frank and I were boys visiting our grandparents at their home in Virginia, just outside of Washington, we used to heckle our grandmother until she would drive us into town so we could visit the Smithsonian museum on the Mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lacy Crawford
title: How to Sell Your Rape Story
description: There’s nothing special about my story. That’s the point.
content: 1. Know that, to rise to the attention of media gatekeepers, your rape story must clear a bar that love and murder and adventure and dragon stories don’t have to clear and be either horrible (gang rape, deep lacerations) or gilded (see No. 2).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: TikTok to Withdraw From Hong Kong as Tech Giants Halt Data Requests
description: Google, Facebook and Twitter said they were reviewing China’s punitive new national security law for the city, a rare public questioning of Chinese policy by major American tech companies.
content: Google, Facebook and Twitter said on Monday that they would temporarily stop processing Hong Kong government requests for user data as the companies reviewed a sweeping national security law that has chilled political expression in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Amy Cooper Faces Charges After Calling Police on Black Bird Watcher
description: Ms. Cooper was captured on video calling the police after Christian Cooper asked her to keep her dog on a leash in Central Park.
content: When Amy Cooper, a white woman, called 911 from an isolated patch in Central Park where she was standing with her unleashed dog on Memorial Day, she said an “African-American man” was threatening her life, emphasizing his race to the operator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: States May Curb ‘Faithless Electors,’ Supreme Court Rules
description: The court said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
content: WASHINGTON — States can require members of the Electoral College to cast their votes for the presidential candidates they had pledged to support, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Monday, curbing the independence of electors and limiting one potential source of uncertainty in the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Virus Revives Italy’s Age-Old Shadow Safety Net: The Pawnshop
description: Italians have put up valuables as collateral for loans for centuries, through plagues and sieges. Today they do it as part of the formal banking system. And business is booming.
content: ROME — The economic repercussions of Italy’s lockdown to contain the coronavirus nearly wiped Anita Paris out. Her son, a car mechanic whom she depended on for financial support, couldn’t work. Her small pension didn’t suffice. The welfare checks she had hoped would pour in from the government didn’t materialize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Breonna Taylor’s Family Claims She Was Alive After Shooting but Given No Aid
description: A new court filing says Ms. Taylor, whose death set off protests, received no medical help after she was shot by the police. The coroner asserts that her injuries were so severe she could not have been saved.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — For up to six minutes after she was shot by police officers during a drug raid, Breonna Taylor, an emergency room technician, lay dying in her apartment but received no medical aid, her family claims in a new court filing.
source.name: The New York Times
